      Raster Graphics

  
       by     
       ManufacturingET.org
     
     ·
                          July 27, 2011
          



                                
      



      
        
          



The smiley face in the top left corner is a bitmap image. When enlarged, individual pixels appear as squares. Zooming in further, they can be analyzed, with their colors constructed by adding the values for red, green and blue.





In computer graphics, a raster graphics image or bitmap is a data structure representing a generally rectangular grid of pixels, or points of color, viewable via a monitor, paper, or other display medium. Raster images are stored in image files with varying formats (see Comparison of graphics file formats).

A bitmap corresponds bit-for-bit with an image displayed on a screen, generally in the same format used for storage in the display’s video memory, or maybe as a device-independent bitmap. A bitmap is technically characterized by the width and height of the image in pixels and by the number of bits per pixel (a color depth, which determines the number of colors it can represent).

The printing and prepress industries know raster graphics as contones (from “continuous tones”) and refer to vector graphics as “line work”.






Contents




1 Etymology

2 Resolution

3 Raster-based image editors

4 See also

5 Article history

6 External links






Etymology

The word “raster” has its origins in the Latin rastrum (a rake), which is derived from radere (to scrape). It originally referred to the raster scan of cathode ray tube (CRT) video monitors, which paint the image line by line by magnetically steering a focused electron beam. By association, it came also to refer to a rectangular grid of pixels. See also rastrum, a device for drawing musical staff lines.

Resolution

Raster graphics are resolution dependent. They cannot scale up to an arbitrary resolution without loss of apparent quality. This property contrasts with the capabilities of vector graphics, which easily scale up to the quality of the device rendering them. Raster graphics deal more practically than vector graphics with photographs and photo-realistic images, while vector graphics often serve better for typesetting or for graphic design. Modern computer-monitors typically display about 72 to 130 pixels per inch (PPI), and some modern consumer printers can resolve 2400 dots per inch (DPI) or more; determining the most appropriate image resolution for a given printer-resolution can pose difficulties, since printed output may have a greater level of detail than a viewer can discern on a monitor. Typically, a resolution of 150 to 300 pixel per inch works well for 4-color process (CMYK) printing.

Raster-based image editors

Raster-based image editors, such as Painter, Photoshop, MS Paint, and GIMP, revolve around editing pixels, unlike vector-based image editors, such as Xfig, CorelDRAW, Adobe Illustrator, or Inkscape, which revolve around editing lines and shapes (vectors). When an image is rendered in a raster-based image editor, the image is composed of millions of pixels. At its core, a raster image editor works by manipulating each individual pixel. Most pixel-based image editors work using the RGB color model, but some also allow the use of other color models such as the CMYK color model.

      <h1 class="post-title entry-title">Raster Graphics</h1>

  <p class="post-byline">
       by     <span class="vcard author">
       <span class="fn"><a href="http://www.manufacturinget.org/author/admin/" title="Posts by ManufacturingET.org" rel="author" target="_blank">ManufacturingET.org</a></span>
     </span>
     ·
                          <span class="published">July 27, 2011</span>
          </p>



                                
      <div class="clear"></div>



      <div class="entry themeform">
        <div class="entry-inner">
          <div class="pf-content"><div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width: 356px;">
<p><a class="image" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Rgb-raster-image.png" target="_blank"><img fetchpriority="high" decoding="async" class="thumbimage" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6e/Rgb-raster-image.png" alt="" width="354" height="400"></a></p>

<div class="thumbcaption">The <a title="Smiley" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Smiley" target="_blank">smiley face</a> in the top left corner is a bitmap image. When enlarged, individual pixels appear as squares. Zooming in further, they can be analyzed, with their colors constructed by adding the values for red, green and blue.</div>

</div>

</div>

<p>In <a title="Computer graphics" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_graphics" target="_blank">computer graphics</a>, a <strong>raster graphics</strong> image or <strong>bitmap</strong> is a <a title="Data structure" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_structure" target="_blank">data structure</a> representing a generally <a title="Rectangle" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Rectangle" target="_blank">rectangular</a> grid of <a title="Pixel" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Pixel" target="_blank">pixels</a>, or points of <a title="Color" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Color" target="_blank">color</a>, viewable via a <a class="mw-redirect" title="Computer display" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_display" target="_blank">monitor</a>, <a title="Paper" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Paper" target="_blank">paper</a>, or other display medium. Raster images are stored in <a class="mw-redirect" title="Image file" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Image_file" target="_blank">image files</a> with varying formats (see <a title="Comparison of graphics file formats" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_graphics_file_formats" target="_blank">Comparison of graphics file formats</a>).</p>

<p>A bitmap corresponds <a title="Bit" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Bit" target="_blank">bit</a>-for-bit with an image displayed on a screen, generally in the same format used for storage in the display’s video memory, or maybe as a device-independent <a title="Bitmap" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitmap" target="_blank">bitmap</a>. A bitmap is technically characterized by the width and height of the image in pixels and by the number of bits per pixel (a <a title="Color depth" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Color_depth" target="_blank">color depth</a>, which determines the number of colors it can represent).</p>

<p>The <a title="Printing" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Printing" target="_blank">printing</a> and <a title="Prepress" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Prepress" target="_blank">prepress</a> industries know raster graphics as <strong>contones</strong> (from “continuous tones”) and refer to <a title="Vector graphics" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Vector_graphics" target="_blank">vector graphics</a> as “line work”.</p>

<table id="toc" class="toc">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>
<div id="toctitle">
<h2>Contents</h2>

</div>

<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="http://www.manufacturinget.org/2011/07/raster-graphics/#Etymology" target="_blank"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Etymology</span></a></li>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="http://www.manufacturinget.org/2011/07/raster-graphics/#Resolution" target="_blank"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Resolution</span></a></li>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="http://www.manufacturinget.org/2011/07/raster-graphics/#Raster-based_image_editors" target="_blank"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Raster-based image editors</span></a></li>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="http://www.manufacturinget.org/2011/07/raster-graphics/#See_also" target="_blank"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="http://www.manufacturinget.org/2011/07/raster-graphics/#Article_history" target="_blank"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Article history</span></a></li>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="http://www.manufacturinget.org/2011/07/raster-graphics/#External_links" target="_blank"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>

</ul>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2><span id="Etymology" class="mw-headline">Etymology</span></h2>

<p>The word “raster” has its origins in the Latin <em><a class="extiw" title="wiktionary:rastrum" href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rastrum" target="_blank">rastrum</a></em> (a rake), which is derived from <em><a class="extiw" title="wiktionary:radere" href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/radere" target="_blank">radere</a></em> (to scrape). It originally referred to the <a title="Raster scan" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Raster_scan" target="_blank">raster scan</a> of <a title="Cathode ray tube" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Cathode_ray_tube" target="_blank">cathode ray tube</a> (CRT) <a class="mw-redirect" title="Video monitor" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_monitor" target="_blank">video monitors</a>, which paint the image line by line by magnetically steering a focused <a class="mw-redirect" title="Electron beam" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Electron_beam" target="_blank">electron beam</a>. By association, it came also to refer to a rectangular grid of pixels. See also <a title="Rastrum" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Rastrum" target="_blank">rastrum</a>, a device for drawing musical staff lines.</p>

<h2><span id="Resolution" class="mw-headline">Resolution</span></h2>

<p>Raster graphics are resolution dependent. They cannot scale up to an arbitrary resolution without <a class="mw-redirect" title="Pixellation" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Pixellation" target="_blank">loss of apparent quality</a>. This property contrasts with the capabilities of <a title="Vector graphics" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Vector_graphics" target="_blank">vector graphics</a>, which easily scale up to the quality of the device <a title="Rendering (computer graphics)" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Rendering_(computer_graphics)" target="_blank">rendering</a> them. Raster graphics deal more practically than vector graphics with photographs and photo-realistic images, while vector graphics often serve better for <a title="Typesetting" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Typesetting" target="_blank">typesetting</a> or for <a title="Graphic design" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphic_design" target="_blank">graphic design</a>. Modern computer-monitors typically display about 72 to 130 <a class="mw-redirect" title="Pixels per inch" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Pixels_per_inch" target="_blank">pixels per inch</a> (PPI), and some modern consumer printers can resolve 2400 <a title="Dots per inch" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Dots_per_inch" target="_blank">dots per inch</a> (DPI) or more; determining the most appropriate image resolution for a given printer-resolution can pose difficulties, since printed output may have a greater level of detail than a viewer can discern on a monitor. Typically, a resolution of 150 to 300 pixel per inch works well for 4-color process (<a class="mw-redirect" title="CMYK" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/CMYK" target="_blank">CMYK</a>) printing.</p>

<h2><span id="Raster-based_image_editors" class="mw-headline">Raster-based image editors</span></h2>

<p>Raster-based image editors, such as <a class="mw-redirect" title="Painter (software)" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Painter_(software)" target="_blank">Painter</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" title="Photoshop" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Photoshop" target="_blank">Photoshop</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" title="MS Paint" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/MS_Paint" target="_blank">MS Paint</a>, and <a title="GIMP" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/GIMP" target="_blank">GIMP</a>, revolve around editing <a class="mw-redirect" title="Pixels" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Pixels" target="_blank">pixels</a>, unlike vector-based image editors, such as <a title="Xfig" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Xfig" target="_blank">Xfig</a>, <a title="CorelDRAW" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/CorelDRAW" target="_blank">CorelDRAW</a>, <a title="Adobe Illustrator" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Adobe_Illustrator" target="_blank">Adobe Illustrator</a>, or <a title="Inkscape" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Inkscape" target="_blank">Inkscape</a>, which revolve around editing lines and shapes (<a title="Vector graphics" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Vector_graphics" target="_blank">vectors</a>). When an image is rendered in a raster-based image editor, the image is composed of millions of pixels. At its core, a raster image editor works by manipulating each individual pixel. Most pixel-based image editors work using the <a title="RGB color model" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/RGB_color_model#Digital_representations" target="_blank">RGB color model</a>, but some also allow the use of other color models such as the <a title="CMYK color model" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/CMYK_color_model" target="_blank">CMYK color model</a>.</p>

<h2><span id="See_also" class="mw-headline">See also</span></h2>

<ul>
<li><a title="Dither" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Dither" target="_blank">Dither</a></li>

<li><a title="Halftone" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Halftone" target="_blank">Halftone</a></li>

<li><a title="GIS file formats" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/GIS_file_formats" target="_blank">GIS file formats</a></li>

<li><a title="Posterization" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Posterization" target="_blank">Posterization</a></li>

<li><a title="Raster image processor" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Raster_image_processor" target="_blank">Raster image processor</a></li>

<li><a title="Raster scan" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Raster_scan" target="_blank">Raster scan</a></li>

<li><a title="Rasterisation" href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Rasterisation" target="_blank">Rasterisation</a></li>
